Work can be a fulfilling and meaningful experience, but it is not always the case. Many people feel undervalued and unappreciated in their jobs. To be successful in today's world, you need to be able to communicate effectively, have a strong mind, and be able to exercise your imagination and humour. If you do not have these skills, no amount of status or financial reward will compensate for your inadequacy as a human being.
To counter this problem, we need to rethink how work is defined and how it can be reconceived to suit us all. This means that we need to be able to design our own jobs, choose our own colleagues, and have more intimate conversations with our customers.
However, there are challenges to this. One challenge is that many employers are not willing to let their employees have too much autonomy. Another challenge is that traditional conversation skills are not always sufficient for the new kind of conversation that is needed in today's world.
Despite these challenges, I believe that we can all work towards a more fulfilling and meaningful work experience. By learning to communicate effectively, have a strong mind, and be able to exercise our imagination and humour, we can all create a more positive and equitable world.

Music and theatre are two different art forms. Opera is primarily a theatre performance, while music comes first in an opera. Music is a powerful and expressive art form that can evoke a wide range of emotions. It can be enjoyed in many different ways, including listening to recordings, attending concerts, and performing. Theatre is also a powerful art form that can evoke a wide range of emotions. It can be enjoyed in many different ways, including watching plays, attending festivals, and participating in acting classes.
There are some similarities between music and theatre. For example, they both require skill and dedication. They also both have the ability to bring people together. And they both have the ability to inspire and entertain.
There are also some differences between music and theatre. For example, music is more focused on sound and rhythm, while theatre is more focused on acting and storytelling. Music is also more portable, while theatre is more confined to specific locations.
Overall, music and theatre are two complementary art forms that can enrich our lives in many ways. They can evoke a wide range of emotions, bring people together, and inspire and entertain.

In those days, the council houses in West Earlham stretched all over the city. They were row after row of huddled, dingy dwellings. In the summer, the chemicals from the May and Baker factory came and hung around the doors and gardens with a smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he negotiated somebody's front path.
My early life has faded away, but I have a memory of sitting on a vantage point near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they faded away into the distance. Later on, there are other phantoms - faces that I can't put names to, my mother ironing towels in the back room of a house that I don't think was ours, snow falling over the turrets of the great mansion at Earlham.
My mother was a small, precise and nearly always angry woman. She was the source of whose anger I never quite understood, and consequently couldn't do anything to appease. As a child, I had some notion of the oddity of her personality. She was, for instance, quite the most solitary person I have ever known. To this solitariness was added a fanatic adhesion to a kind of propriety uncommon on the West Earlham estate.
Growing up in West Earlham at this time followed a well-regulated pattern. Until you were five, you simply sat at home and got under your parents feet. Then, the September after your fifth birthday, you were packed off to Avenue Road infants school half a mile away in the direction of the city.
If I remember anything about these early years it's the summer holidays, those days when you caught occasional glimpses of the world that existed outside West Earlham. Mercenary motives were a familiar theme of my mother's conversation, and politicians my mother held in the deepest contempt of all.

The Earth is getting warmer and this is causing changes to the weather in all parts of the world. Plants and animals are being affected by these changes, as well as water and soils. Humans have learned to use natural resources to their advantage, but any changes to these resources have to be taken seriously.
The problem is that we do not fully understand the processes of the climatic system. We also do not know exactly how the world will change in the future. However, most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have previously experienced.
Some of the predicted effects of future climate warming are far from beneficial. These include changes in precipitation patterns, changes in glacial processes, and rising sea levels. The consequences of rising sea levels are potentially very severe, with many people losing their homes and livelihoods.
It is important to take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to mitigate the effects of climate change. We also need to develop new technologies to help us adapt to the changing climate.

Aesthetics is a field that studies the theory of art. However, the existence of artworks often creates obstacles to understanding aesthetic theory. One reason is that artworks are physical products that exist outside of human experience. They are often identified with the building, book, painting, or statue in its existence apart from human experience. This makes it difficult to understand the meaning of artistic products. Additionally, the perfection of some artworks creates conventions that get in the way of fresh insight. When artworks are isolated from their original conditions and human consequences, they become difficult to understand. In order to understand the meaning of artistic products, we have to forget them for a time and have recourse to the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. We must arrive at the theory of art by means of a detour.

They also have to deal with increasingly being asked to do their ever more difficult jobs with smaller and smaller budgets.

These include the economic situation, the controversy over production costs, and the disinclination to take risks. Tiredness has become a common condition in modern society. In the USA, research has found that 40 million Americans are chronically affected by sleeplessness. People often cut back on sleep when they are busy. They get up too early to avoid the rush hour.
There are some things that scientists know about human sleep. Humans sleep according to a daily cycle. Once asleep, they switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. Dreams occur during the lightest sleep.
However, there are also many theories about what sleep is for. Some scientists believe that sleep repairs body tissue or restores muscles. Others believe that sleep rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity. There is no evidence to support these theories.
Despite these uncertainties, there are some things that we can be certain of. Women sleep for half an hour longer than men, and older people require less sleep.

I was at Easter Monday in Buccoo Village to witness goat racing. There were a lot of people and food stalls at the event. I had to fight my way through the crowds to get a good spot. There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed at lightning speeds; others take seconds, minutes, hours, days or even years to complete their course. Some can be speeded up - we can become quicker at solving crossword puzzles or doing mental arithmetic. But others cannot be rushed, and if they are, then they will break down, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled up, like the fishing line.
The mind possesses three different processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. The second is thought itself: the sort of intelligence which does involve figuring matters out, weighing up the pros and cons, constructing arguments and solving problems. The third is slower and more purposeful, more playful, leisurely or dreamy.

Maps are used to show the relationships of points and features on the Earth's surface. They are determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than about actual distance. Direction is also an important element of maps. The accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance for ordinary travellers. Written itineraries for a long time rivalled maps. Today, certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, may make little attempt to show true directions. Landmarks along a route were at first indicated by signs. The history of cartography is largely that of the increase in the accuracy with which distance and direction are determined and the comprehensiveness of the map content. The development of cartography has called in other sciences to its aid. Today, cartographers have to evolve methods of mapping all kinds of 'distributions', from geological strata and climatic regimes to land use.

The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964, a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. The students were in for the flight of their lives. Inside, it had become a long white tunnel. There were almost no windows, but it was eerily illuminated by lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats had been ripped out, apart from a few at the back, where the pale-faced, budding scientists took their places. The flight was smooth, but the engines strained wildly, and the passengers were scattered across the cabin floor. After a few seconds of freefall descent, the pilot pulled the aircraft out of its nose dive. The return of gravity was less immediate than its loss, but was still sudden enough to ensure that some of the students came down with a bump. After two hours spent swinging between heaven and Earth, that morning's breakfast felt unstable, but the predominant sensation was exhilaration, not nausea.

I planted trees in New Zealand. I had a lot of winters there. I also had a lot of summers. My parents bought a small plot of land which I could look after. I started planting trees in 1968. The trees are now 20 years old. I enjoy hard physical work. I also enjoy writing. I wrote my first book there. The connection between me and that area is still immensely strong.

Six years ago, I turned my dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' and have established a reputation for looking after orphaned animals. One day, I found three small grey badger cubs. Their coats were like velvet, and milky-coloured eyes looked up at me from three tiny black-and-white striped heads. I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and installed them beside the stove for warmth.
The cubs were fed every four hours and grew quickly. After a few weeks, they were able to drink from a bottle and move around. They were very contented. However, one of the cubs, Willow, became lethargic and died from a lung infection. I was heartbroken by my failure, but fate worked in strange ways. Six days later, I found another male cub, Willow II, who was abandoned by his mother.
Willow II joined the fold and grew quickly. He was happy to give up the bottle but could not master the habit of eating without walking through his food. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which little by little was chewed, played with and finally eaten. After a week of sausages, he was ready to move on to something else.
The cubs are now eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch and fruit and nuts, cheese, hardboiled eggs and sunflower seeds in the evening. They are also digging for earthworms. As 'human badgers', we often go for walks with the cubs in the evening. We see Primrose only occasionally, but Bluebell and Willow II still rush up to say hello before they go dashing off into the night.

Sir Edmund Halley was a famous astronomer who lived in the 17th century. He is best known for his discovery of the comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was to chart the variations of the compass. These variations are now known as declination. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans. Halley's journey was the first dedicated scientific expedition on the seas. He became the first civilian who was appointed naval captain to pursue what many regarded as an obsession with declination.
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to retrace Halley's voyage. He has already sailed the 13,000 kilometres from Rio de Janeiro to England. He envisages that the expedition will be completed in four stages, with four different crews. Dr. Clark is prepared to give up his life for eight months to do this. He believes that Halley's accomplishments deserve to be celebrated.

Peacocks that live at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire, UK, show off their magnificent trains to the hens. The peacocks' trains are very impressive, but they are not necessarily advantageous. Darwin argued that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, and that the principal mechanism of evolution was natural selection. According to Darwin, the fittest individuals are the most likely to survive and reproduce. However, the peacocks' tail was not an end in itself, but an advertisement for some genuine contribution to survival.
The zoologist Marion Petrie and her colleagues are trying to find out if the peacocks with the showiest trains also have some extra, genuinely advantageous quality. They have identified two main questions. First, is the premise correct - do peahens really choose the males with the showiest trains? And, secondly, do the peacocks with the showiest trains have some extra, genuinely advantageous quality, as Wallace supposed, or is it really all show, as Darwin felt?
The results of their research could help to settle the debate between Darwin and Wallace about the peacocks' tails. If the males with the best trains are also 'better' in other ways, then the females' choice will be seen to be utilitarian after all, just as Wallace predicted.

The best boat design combines old and new. Tom Cunliffe says that. He designed his own boat, 'The Westerman', which is at the Summer Boat Show in London this week. The boat has all the benefits of a glass fibre boat yet looks like, feels like and sails like the real thing.
The boat was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. It has a lot of old-fashioned boat design features, but also has the benefits of modern technology. The boat has a coal stove for warmth and dryness, cosy berths for sleeping, and a lot of storage space.
However, the boat also has some drawbacks. It is difficult to sail and it is expensive to maintain. But for Cunliffe, the boat is worth it. He loves sailing and he is happy that he was able to build his own boat.

Health farms and country house hotels offering spa facilities are popular among stressed working women. Many of these places provide a variety of treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The atmosphere at these places is typically calm and relaxing.
If you are feeling stressed and need a break, you might consider visiting one of these health farms or country house hotels. There are many benefits to staying at these places, including the opportunity to relax, improve your mood, and lose weight.
Some of the most popular treatments at these places include aromatherapy, massages, and body conditioning. You can also enjoy a variety of activities, such as walking in the garden, swimming, or playing tennis.
If you are interested in learning more about health farms and country house hotels, you can read the reports written by journalists who have stayed at these places. You can also find information online about the different treatments and activities that are available at these places.

In the past few million years, humans and chimpanzees have not had much time to develop differences. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. Our biological history implies that our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to just a tiny fraction of our genes.
Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many attributes once considered uniquely human are also used by animals. For example, tools are used by humans and chimpanzees, and sea otters crack open clams with rocks. As for language, monkeys have a simple one, with separate warning sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle' and 'snake'.
If human art sprang from a unique genetic endowment, it's strange that our ancestors dispensed with it for at least the first 6.9 million of the 7 million years since they diverged from chimps. The earliest art forms may well have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved.
There are three supposed distinctions between human art and animal activities. First, human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and it's transmitted by learning rather than by genes. Second, human art is not motivated by aesthetic pleasure. Third, human art is a learned rather than an instinctive activity.
These paintings by our closest relatives, then, do start to blur some distinctions between human art and animal activities. Like human paintings, the ape paintings served no narrow utilitarian functions; they were produced not for material regard but only for the painter's satisfaction.

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale.
There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to specialize in them. These days you no longer find such people in fiction, let alone in real life.
Blackmore's great adventure consisted of leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert. The team was composed of four Britons, an American photographer, four Chinese, 30 camels and six camel handlers.
The team suffered unspeakable hardships, but they managed to find water and survive. They walked for 1,000 kilometres and were very thin and muscular despite their physical exhaustion.
Blackmore went on to describe lying in the desert gazing up at a full moon, thinking of his family. He felt prouder of that expedition than of anything else he'd done.

Life was getting out of hand. Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and rediscover the joys of manual labour. Everyone loves technology. It makes life easier and leaves us with more time to do other things. However, a recent experience with her malfunctioning word processor has confirmed a suspicion that gadgets are often not worth the expense or the trouble. Are we as dependent on technology as we imagine? Susan has been letting the household technology fall by the wayside as its natural and often short life expires. She is not tied to a noisy, whirring machine, and she can take her time over the garment. She also finds that she can sew and listen to the radio, or talk with family and friends, while she is sewing.

The cabinet-maker Charles Hurst makes furniture. He is very busy and has a lot of work. He has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built up a very nice reputation for himself. His order book is always full for several months in advance.
Hurst is passionate about his craft and takes pride in making beautifully crafted furniture. He is also critical of shoddy, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who churn out second-rate pieces.
If you want a decent cupboard or table, bookcase or kitchen units, Hurst is your man. You can find a furniture-maker easily, but finding a cabinet-maker who prides himself on making beautifully crafted furniture with clean, simple lines is less easy.

People spend a third of their lives asleep. Sleep is important for our health. It helps us to repair damage and restore ourselves to full efficiency. There are three main theories about why we sleep. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our health. It helps us to repair damage and restore ourselves to full efficiency. The second theory says that sleep is mainly for learning. It helps us to process information that we acquire during the day. The third theory says that sleep is mainly for energy. It helps us to recharge our batteries and have an adequate supply of energy for the coming day.

Someone who behaves in a way that is different from the majority of people is called eccentric. Eccentricity is the assertion of our individuality. It is the desire to be unique and to do things differently from others. Most of us have our own quirks and oddities. It may be a passion for doing something that is not common to others, a compulsion for collecting things that are unique, or a tendency to express ourselves in a way that is different from the norm. Eccentricity is not necessarily a bad thing. It can be a source of strength and creativity. However, if someone's eccentricity becomes too extreme and interferes with their ability to function normally, it can be a problem.

Natural books have influenced many people. Some of the most influential books include Only One Earth, Progress for a Small Planet, The Home of Man, Signals for Survival, and My Family and Other Animals.
The Home of Man is a book about the explosive growth of the world's cities. It is a compelling book that has inspired many people to care about the environment.
Signals for Survival is a book about animal communication. It explains beautifully the fascinating world of animal communication through words and pictures.
My Family and Other Animals is a book about the importance of conservation. It is a book that has inspired many people to take action to protect the natural world.
The Shell Bird Book is a book about birds. It is a book that has inspired many people to learn more about birds and the natural world.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of book reviews on their commercial success. They said that reviews are very important for publishers. They said that reviews can help to sell books and that they often look for reviews that precisely echo their own response to a book. However, publishers also said that reviews are not the only factor that affects book sales. Other factors include the book's content, the book's price, and the book's availability.

The making of weathervanes is an ancient craft that has been going on for centuries. Today, the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers. He can produce a unique personalized item. A lot of his customers are women buying presents for their husbands. They want a distinctive gift that represents the man's business or leisure interests.
Graham has perfected over 100 original designs. He works to very fine detail, always seeking approval for the design of the silhouette from the customer before proceeding with the hand-cutting. Graham also keeps plenty of traditional designs in stock.
Graham has become increasingly busy, supplying flat-packed weathervanes to clients worldwide. American and Danish buyers in particular are showing interest. 'Pricing,' he explains, 'depends on the intricacy of the design.'

The Horse Whisperer was a popular book that was published in the year it was released. It was written by a British screenwriter named Nicholas Evans. The book earned Evans a lot of money.
The first months of the year were not kind to Evans. He was disappointed when his film project, Life and Limb, fell through. He was also worried about his finances. He thought that he might need to get a job. Instead of getting a job, Evans decided to write his first novel. He spent a lot of time researching the subject and writing the book.
The book was eventually sold to a publisher for a lot of money. The book was a success and Evans was able to earn a lot of money from it. He was also able to use the money to help others.

Young Masters Age is against Bobby Fischer as he seeks to re-establish himself in chess. Chess is more than ever a young man's game. After 20 years of self-imposed exile, Mr Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing his old adversary Boris Spassky. Mr Fischer's victory in the first game was a masterpiece, simple but profound. But, as subsequent games have shown, this balding, bearded chess player is not the man of 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice and out of shape. The game has also changed a lot over the past two decades. The new era of professionalism was born out of Mr Fischer's own popularisation of the game. The rise of the professional chess circuit has seen the competitive aspect of the game overtake the scientific and artistic. The main goal of the modern master is to win. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as crucial as his intellect and wisdom. The pressure of the game has always been intense, but now the playing sessions themselves are becoming longer, and many games are played without a break. The increased pressure has swung the pendulum in youth's favour. Over the past 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than his predecessor. The game is played off the board as well as on it. The presence of the chess clock adds to the tension. The climax of the game is often a furious 'time scramble'. With minds racing and hands twitching, the masters blitz out their moves and press their clocks with a co-ordination that any athlete would admire.

Fame and fortune are two things that many people dream of, and the stories of the new British talent in this article are no exception. There are a few young people who have achieved great success in their chosen fields, from the stage to the music industry.
Nick Grosso is a playwright who has written three critically acclaimed plays. He is currently adapting his first play, Peaches, into a screenplay. Simon Pegg is a comedian who is writing a television comedy series and has just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Ciaran McMenamin is an actor who has gained a lot of recognition for his role in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. Neil Taylor is a pop singer who has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Stephen Richards is a poet and author who has won more prizes than anyone twice his age.
These young people have all achieved great success through hard work and determination. They are an inspiration to anyone who dreams of achieving their own goals.

In a novel, 'Our Hero Feels Inspired', the author writes with terrific verve. The story is about a young art student named Isabel who seeks Mr Right but is concerned lest her knobbly knees ruin her chances. Hope springs eternal for Isabel, and it also proves to be her salvation. The author skillfully transports the reader from the present back to the gentler days of the 1940s and 1950s. The story is well-written and enjoyable.

Volunteer tourism is a topic that four academic writers discuss. It can be a positive or negative experience. On the one hand, volunteering can lead to greater international understanding, enhanced ability to solve conflicts, and growth of international social networks. It can also raise awareness of existing unequal power relations and deep-seated causes of poverty. On the other hand, volunteer tourism can be imperialist, paternalistic charity, or a self-serving quest for career and personal development. It can also bypass the democratic imperative of representative government and reduce development to individual acts of charity.
Most significantly, volunteering can raise awareness of, and a lifelong commitment to combating, existing unequal power relations and deep-seated causes of poverty. However, volunteer tourism seems to fit well with the growth of life strategies to help others. Such limited strategies, aimed at a humble 'making a difference', can appear positive and attractive in an anti-political climate.

Many people listen to the radio when they wake up in the morning. To wake up, most people need some external means. One common way to wake up is the clock radio. But how do you pick a good one? Our panel, which consisted of myself, Tom Granger, and Paul Bridges, tested five currently available clock radios.
We all thought the quality of the radios was excellent, but we found that the biggest one was too big for our bedside tables. The biggest radio was as big as a rugby ball. We also found that the radios were difficult to set up. However, we all agreed that the radios worked well once they were set up.
The simplest and cheapest of all the models tested, this one scored points with Tom Granger because it 'seemed very standard and took up little space'.

A hedgehog is a small mammal that has sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many different parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. Hedgehogs have the ability to roll into a tight ball when they are attacked. The number of spines a hedgehog has affects its ability to defend itself. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to carry out weight, and consequently, they have fewer spines and are more likely to attempt to run into their attacker, using their ball rolling ability as a last resort. Hedgehogs are primarily nocturnal and sleep for much of the day. Despite the fact that all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all choose to do so.

To excel in any sport is difficult, even for men. Women have to be even tougher. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. But against all the odds, women are beating prejudice and breaking records.
Here, we talk to just a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
A. Jill, a skier, says, "It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. You just get on with it. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months of the year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice."
B. Caroline, a cyclist, says, "I'm well paid as a pro, and cycling has lots of potential in terms of endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly and it worries me that people may think I've got where I'm because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I tend to concentrate on the cycling at the moment, rather than earning money."
C. Annabel, a rower, says, "Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools do it. So most don't start till they're 19 or 20 which makes it harder to succeed at an international level."
D. Ffyona, a long-distance walker, says, "I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record!"
E. Lisa, a saloon car racer, says, "Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks!"
F. Alison, a triathlete, says, "I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes!"

I was travelling around Europe and Morocco in a van when I met Picasso. I found a boat-painting job on the waterfront and spent much of my time drawing. One day, I met Picasso at a restaurant in Cannes harbour. He was seated with his wife and three companions. I was able to ask him for his signature and he agreed to give me a drawing. I was surprised by his generosity and the quality of his drawing. I felt like I was in a dream.

Talking shop Ever entered a store and bought more than you intended to buy? Supermarkets know that shoppers like to buy fresh produce. They often place their fruit and veg at the entrance of the store or even a display of house plants for sale. They may also provide an in-store bakery that wafts irresistible fresh bread smells around the store.
Supermarkets also use lighting to attract shoppers. They use special lighting to enhance certain foods, particularly fresh fruit and veg. They also use lighting to create a warm and inviting atmosphere.
Many chainstores have divided up their floors with different carpeting. One pattern for the routes through a store and one defining sales areas. Shoppers are drawn naturally along these routes known within the trade as the 'Yellow Brick Road'.
As you enter a supermarket, giant colour photographs of succulent roasts, fancy cakes and cheeses hit you. Supermarkets often use in-store promotion to attract shoppers. They use giant colour photographs to advertise products. They also use video trolleys to advertise products.

Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston are known for their achievements in climbing and sailing. Chris Bonnington has climbed the summit of Everest and pioneered routes in Britain and the Alps. Robin Knox-Johnston was the first to circumnavigate the world single-handedly. They have written books about their adventures. One day, Chris invited Robin to join him on a trip to Skye. They sailed and climbed together, and built a strong friendship. The trip to Greenland was even more memorable. They faced challenges and overcame obstacles together. They also had a near-crisis on the way home. Despite their differences, they were able to work together and enjoy their time together.

Apples have been with humans since the beginning of time. They are grown all over the world. There are many different varieties of apples. Some apples are red, some are green, and some are yellow. Apples are often eaten with meals. They can also be used to make juice, cider, and other drinks.
In the past, apples were grown in many different places. They were grown in Europe, Asia, and America. They were also grown in Africa and Australia. Today, apples are grown in many different countries. They are grown in India, Africa, and the US.
Apples are a healthy and nutritious fruit. They are full of vitamins and minerals. They are also a good source of fiber. Eating apples can help you to stay healthy.

Explore Worldwide offers a variety of adventure travel experiences designed for people who want to get more out of their holiday than just a beach. The company specializes in travel to new and unusual destinations, coupled with interesting and original itineraries. Explore Worldwide has a brochure containing over 100 original adventures in more than 60 countries around the world. Most trips last from 1-4 weeks and are led by small informal groups of 16 people.
The company offers a wide range of activities, including hiking, safaris, and river journeys. They also provide opportunities to meet ethnic peoples and explore remote wilderness areas. Explore Worldwide emphasizes sustainability and aims to help spread tolerance and understanding between different races and peoples.
Overall, Explore Worldwide provides a unique and memorable travel experience for those who want to explore the world in a way that goes beyond the typical tourist attractions.

The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator and is surrounded by beautiful playing fields and dense tropical vegetation. The athletes live in cinder-block dormitories and train hard every day. They run early in the morning, do interval training at mid-morning, and run steadily in the late afternoon. The daily regime begins at six and includes a leisurely run, interval training, and a steady run. Running apart, life is simple and uncomplicated. The athletes eat a simple diet and bathe in the streams that run off from Mt Kenya's shrinking glaciers.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main reason for the decline is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. Advertising is also fragmented because brands and media have proliferated. As a result, most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised.
Even when you throw in confectionery, medicines, hardware, all the services you can think of, it is virtually certain you do not buy more than 400 different brands a year. The most cost-effective way to reach the relevant minority is to use mass media, but if advertising is to get going again its message will need to be more tightly targeted than ever before.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside Britain's most environmentally-friendly home, Southwell in Nottinghamshire. The house is designed to be energy-efficient and sustainable. It uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles its sewage into garden compost, and heats the house with waste heat from electrical appliances and its own body heat. The house is also super-insulated with krypton-filled triple-glazed windows. There is a monastic stillness inside the house. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, were serious about the environment long before it hit the political agenda. They wrote a book on green architecture back in the 1970s, The Autonomous House. They designed a building which emitted no carbon dioxide. The house has a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which the Vales claim not to use except in the very coldest winter. So is it warm in winter? One night in February when I happened to call on him, Robert was sitting reading. It was too warm to light the fire, he said. The room temperature on the first floor was 18C, less than the generally expected temperature of living areas, but entirely comfortable, he claimed, because there are no draughts, no radiant heat loss.

The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie.

Blacksmiths have been skilled craftsmen for many years. They have been making weapons, armour and farming tools. In the past, blacksmiths were highly respected and were often compared to doctors and astrologers. Today, blacksmiths are not as widely used, but they are still admired for their artistry.
There has been a recent revival of blacksmithing. This is due to greater interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design. Many blacksmiths are now able to express themselves more freely thanks to power tools. They can bend, split, twist and spot-weld the metal with relative ease.
No other base metal can have given man as much visual pleasure, or a greater feeling of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are good.

The day I gave up smoking, I was pleased that everyone would be happy. But one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she raged. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I guess my inability to explain how I had been a smoker for many years and how I was not anymore was a little annoying. The stop-smoking session was an interesting mixture of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I had not intended to stop and I did not even particularly want to. But I did stop. The physical craving and the pangs of desire for nicotine faded after a few days. I am increasingly coming to the view that smoking had a great deal to do with displacing boredom. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also a mother of three and wife to a historian.
Hodgkin's most important successes were solving the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12. She pushed the technique into realms of complexity others deemed unreachable at the time.
There is much to learn from Hodgkin's life. She was a successful scientist and a loving mother. Her story is an inspiration to all.

Margaret Wilkins is said to have a special ability to find water. She can hold a forked hazel stick above the ground and detect water. She is very busy these days because there has been a lot of drought. Most of her customers are farmers with wells that have dried up. To find water, Margaret uses a map and a hazel stick. She also checks the land with her hazel stick. If she finds water, she will reel slightly and use the stick to locate the exact spot where they should drill.

**
We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Perhaps you think it would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
A. Amanda's story I couldn't believe how dark and noisy it was at the restaurant. It was all a far cry from my home town and, to he honest, I wasn't sure I'd survive! Being a mother is definitely a busy job - but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks at shoulder height with one hand. The other waitresses made it look so simple, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and crashed on to the floor, splattering cocktails everywhere.
B. Cindy's story I was feeling quite apprehensive about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. As Amanda left to make her way to the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the settee into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming as loudly as they possibly could. I decided to take the laid-back approach, imagining they'd soon get worn out. Wrong again.
C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up early and sleep late. It was a lonely day. The income is irregular and I'd hate to be at the mercy of the weather.
D. Hilary's story I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk and squeezing ice-cream from a machine. It was difficult to stop myself dipping my fingers into the goodies! The worst aspect of the job is not being able to get away from work.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He was born in southern Sweden and has a unique talent for playing the trumpet. His records are continually opening up new repertory, not just concertos by long-neglected composers, but new works too.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo and owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father had the idea of giving his only son a trumpet. The success of the gift was instant. The boy never stopped playing.
Hardenberger has a gift for finding the right compromise and making a relationship with the imperfections of the trumpet. He has always thought of himself as a solo artist pure and simple. From early boyhood he had as a role-model the French trumpeter, Maurice Andre.
Hardenberger's realism about his work and his career may sound arrogant, but that would be a totally false impression. He is a thoughtful and humble musician who is passionate about his work.

New In Paperback A is a novel set in the fictional republic of Efica. The book is notable for its humour, and for the author's unique vision. It also includes a story about a teenage boy who viciously attacked a young man. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. The book follows the fortunes of one of the most isolated of the Scottish Orkney islands and its inhabitants over a long and uneventful rural history. The book also includes a story about a woman who approaches her seventies with her spirited companion.
The author is skillful at exposing the haunting sadness that hovers beneath the seeming ordinariness of life. He is attuned more to the shadows than the bright lights of human activity and identifies the randomness of events.

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who discuss their different professions. Each woman has a unique job and a unique set of challenges and rewards.

B. The Senior Designer

When the 40km cycle ride is over, you have to run 1Okm, which is a long way when you're feeling exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end,' she says.

These seeds are dried and become cacao beans. Cacao beans can be used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl. The Spanish found the drink more palatable mixed with cinnamon and sugar. Chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate was made from solid blocks of chocolate which had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, chocolate powder was invented. The age of the chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847. Today, chocolate intake in Britain has stabilised at about four bars each week.

Peter Cooke is a shell artist who is known for his unique and delicate creations. He has been making beautiful objects out of shells for the past ten years. His work is admired for its attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry.
Cooke collects dead shells from beaches all over the world. He uses these shells to create a variety of items, including ornaments, flowers, and boxes. His work is often displayed in art galleries.
Cooke is passionate about his art and is always willing to share his knowledge with others. He is also a very humble person and does not want to be praised for his work.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on magazine covers, she is usually studying for her school exams. One day, she was late for her appointment because she had to revise for her exams. She was worried that she would be rushed and in a bad mood. But when she arrived, she was smiling, relaxed and apologetic. She was not dressed in expensive clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. She explained that all models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. Kira has the looks, ability and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They believe their mine on the side of a Welsh mountain could contain a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a vein of gold worth millions of dollars.
The pair have dedicated their lives to the hunt for gold. They started their search after the father read about a pocket of gold worth millions of pounds buried in the Welsh town of Dolgellau. Since they started digging, they have spent the past ten years getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth, and removing old cars and rubbish.
Now they are running short of money. They will have to convince a backer to put money into the project to lower the mine just a few more metres to where the gold lies.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into steep decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples, and then three hours to get back up to the surface.
If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. It's like letting go of a ping-pong ball in the bath.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. She loves teaching and she does it so she can get on with her research.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more punishment. I was tired of foreign timetables, currencies and languages. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. The train ticket allowed me to travel freely throughout Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've slept in the corridor of a train. Carrying all your possessions on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel. It encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks and getting rid of books when finished. But this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. You can travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time.

There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not with you, you may have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days until the airline reunites you with your luggage. Although airlines rarely reveal how many cases they lose, it is a fact of life that sooner or later regular travellers will be parted from their luggage. The system works like this. Airlines require you to check in at a specific time before your flight. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are designed to allow for baggage transfers. Sometimes, extra security checks and problems with air traffic can cause delays. All this can cause the baggage system to fail. If your luggage goes missing, you must contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR). This must be done before leaving the airport.

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has gone in a split second, but a trace of the image lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent a lot of time watching them. He has a lot of photographs of kingfishers.

Conducting an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson is a young conductor who works with a well-established opera company in London. She has conducted several projects with Claudio Abbado.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label.
C. Wasfi Kani started conducting seriously in her late twenties. She loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He has conducted several pieces of music.
E. Wayne Marshall is a young conductor who has conducted several musical productions. He is determined and knows what he likes.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best. Fun Island, Wonderland, Adventure World, The Great Park, and Fantasy World are all popular theme parks in Britain. Each park has its own unique attractions.
At Fun Island, there are rides for younger children, such as the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's also a special dodgems ride for the very young kids. For older children, there are scarier rides, such as Splash Out.
At Wonderland, there are rides that are perfect for younger children, such as the Mountain Train and Little Land. There's also a ferris wheel and toy cars.
At Adventure World, there are rides that are perfect for older children, such as the Big Top Circus and the Terror Line. There's also a ride called Running River where you think you're going to get soaked, but you don't.
At The Great Park, there are rides that are perfect for younger children, such as Exotic Travels and Lightning River. There's also a big leap ride called Big Leap.
At Fantasy World, there are rides that are perfect for older children, such as the Rocket and the Hanger. There's also a long slide ride called Long Slide.

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. Each woman has a different story and a different way of running her business.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She has a lot of customers and she can work from home.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She enjoys being independent and she has a big room upstairs.
C. Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She has seen good times and bad times, but she is still running her business.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business. She enjoys being able to work when she wants to and she has a lot of international deals.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She started small and has grown her business to a large size.

The Watkins family is a group of musicians. They live in South Wales, UK. The sons, Paul and Huw, are composers and prize-winning musicians. Their dad, John, makes the instruments.
One day, John needed to get his son a cello. He decided to make one himself. He took evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making. After a few tries, he made a cello that was perfect for Paul.
Paul started playing the cello when he was young. He won a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He is now playing a new cello that was loaned to him from the Royal Academy of Music.
Huw is also a musician. He plays the piano and is a composer. He is beginning to make his own mark as a musician.
The Watkins family is proud of their sons' musical achievements. They are excited to see what the future holds for them.

The National Trust is an organisation that conserves the British countryside. Gareth Roberts is a warden employed by the Trust to look after the beautiful areas it owns. To be a National Trust Warden, you need to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he married. He has come to understand more about nature conservation since he has been with the Trust. Conservation is one of the main aspects of Gareth's work. His role is to make sure jobs get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible.

The Netball Captain
Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused when she is playing. She doesn't see anything else except her movements and her feet. She might notice cars slow down out of the corner of her eye, but that's all.
The World Championships are big and important for Kendra. She wants to make sure she is at her absolute best for the Championships. She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for them.
The first game of the Championships is against Barbados. Kendra says that they have always beaten Barbados, but they will be excited to play.
Kendra is proud of her career and she is excited about the future of netball. She is sure that the sport will continue to grow and become even more popular.

A child who shows outstanding musical ability may need a special understanding and education. There are five music schools in Britain that provide a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. These schools offer a range of musical activities, including individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also provide a restricted academic programme, which concentrates on the essential subjects.
The disadvantages of attending a specialist music school include the cost and the need to board away from home. It may also be better to wait until the child is old enough to be able to make their own decisions before considering a specialist education.
For those who are equally gifted academically, there are other options. You can combine a normal school routine with musical training at one of the junior departments at the music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning opportunities for individual lessons with fine teachers, plus orchestral and chamber music experience.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.
The text has been simplified by removing unnecessary details and repetitions, and the language has been made more concise and clear. The overall structure of the text has been preserved, and the answerability of the questions associated with it has not been affected.

Keeping the holiday-makers happy is a chalet girl's work. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex who works as a chalet girl in Val d'lsere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and prepares the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible. In the evening, she prepares dinner, takes a shower, and chats with her friends.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. If she hasn't already done the week's shop, she does it now. Between tea and dinner, she takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of a magazine. She went to a photo studio, press previews, and a fashion shoot. She enjoyed her job at the zoo more than her job at the magazine.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at the London Zoo. She stroked an elephant and thought about her future career.
Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with a television gardening programme. She was excited to be in the fresh air and felt strong despite her hard work.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at the hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. He felt satisfied despite his job being a waste of time.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt different and self-conscious when she put on the uniform.
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was surprised by the amount of attention given to one person and felt satisfied with her job.

On the rails, five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. Andrea Thompson, a newsreader, fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and tries to get back there as often as she can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast which crosses the border with Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing seascapes. The journey is always enchanting, regardless of the weather or time of the year. You feel like someone peeping into the property of the rich and famous. The travellers themselves are always lively because there is an interesting mix of tourists and locals, all with different itineraries but all admirers of the breathtaking journey.
Raj Patel, an explorer, has enjoyed many rail journeys through the years, but if he had to pick a favourite, it would be the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert of northern Sudan. The journey was filled with misfortune, but it was also a memorable one. Betty Cooper, a novelist, is indebted to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took her and her husband on their honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. The journey was filled with love and happiness. Martin Brown, a journalist, was working on a series of articles based on a round-the-world trip and had to cross a dessert in an African country. The train journey was unreliable and dangerous, but it was also a dream-like experience. Arisu Mezuki, an actress, imagines most people's favourite impressions of trains and railways are formed when they are young children, but that's not her case. She was brought up in Singapore and Cyprus, where she saw very few trains, let alone travelled on them. It wasn't until she was a teenager that trains began to dominate her life.

If you want to get your story published, there are a few things you need to know. First, you need to research your market and find out about publishers. You also need to practice your writing skills. To become a successful writer, you need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at. You can do this by reading everything relevant you can lay your hands on. Use your local library and go round the local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will always give you the best guide to what kinds of writing publishers are actually accepting at any given time.
Once you have researched your market and improved your writing skills, you can start sending your work to publishers. However, it is important to remember that most new writers are not successful. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not at all likely to be published. Don't be discouraged if your work is rejected. Just keep writing and eventually you will be successful.

I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10.10 to Philadelphia. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples with matching luggage and swarms of college kids. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He was well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. He was probably worried about his daughter. He was talking about his daughter and her passport. He said he had to stay with his wife because she was in a wheelchair. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. The man was holding a packet. It looked to be stapled shut. I said silently, "Watch yourself, lady."

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Gary was given his chance to shine in the kitchen, and his dad ran a restaurant. When John heard about an opportunity, he rushed to look at the place. It was perfect for his business. John and his wife dedicated themselves to running the restaurant and raising their children. They lived over the restaurant and always put a lot of emphasis on having meals together.
Gary was a lively child who loved to cook. He started helping his dad in the kitchen at a young age. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there. He went to catering college and started his own business. Gary is successful and has a lot of talent. He's helped other people out and is proud of his accomplishments.
John is proud of his son and believes that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. He also thinks that if you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they only take in ten per cent of what you've told them, you should be happy.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true.
She went to the flat and met a cheerful-looking girl with a college scarf. The girl was coming down the stairs and said, "Is this all there is to it? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent.
They offered her a mug of tea and she stayed for a while.

Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent, sensitive to human emotions, and allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
The main cause of death for dolphins is being caught in fishermen's nets. This is because porpoises have to find their food within a limited time. If fish in one area are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. Dolphins are also in danger of getting caught in fishermen's nets which are thought to be invisible to them.
Another threat to dolphins is pollution. Waste and other substances found in the sea can be stored in the bodies of dolphins. One example is what happens with pesticides: these poisons are soluble in fat, which means that the dolphins can digest them and they can build up in their bodies.
Finally, dolphins are also threatened by human disturbance. Noise pollution from ships, oil wells and other sources can disturb the dolphins in ways that we do not yet understand.

Getting fit is essential for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to maintain a perfect balance when everything seems more and more unbalanced. There are plenty of reasons why you should exercise and very few - for most of us why you shouldn't. Exercise improves muscle tone and provides quick changes in body shape. It helps prevent muscle imbalances which can lead to injuries. It also improves the condition of your heart and lungs and blood circulation. If you're not sure, you should consult your doctor on what's good for you personally. Stretching is a great way to improve flexibility and ease of movement, and helps you to maintain correct posture and to prevent muscle tears and injuries caused by overuse. If done four or five times a week, it will guarantee a more flexible,fitter body. So stretching should play an important part in your exercise routine, which should be performed both slowly and precisely.

In their natural habitat, film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are currently trailing a shy animal, the jackal. Film-makers have been travelling the world to point cameras at exotic wildlife since the birth of television. The appeal of being alone in such remote areas is that we can get close enough to the animals to become part of their lives.

The Netball Captain
Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused on her training. She said, "My whole life now is all about making sure I'm at my absolute best for the Championships." She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for the Championships.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the England team. But Kendra is confident that they can win. She said, "You don't do all that training not to come out a winner."
Netball is also taking a far more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players."
As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She said, "From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned." So she took the decision some time ago that this competition would be the end of it as far as playing is concerned.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
A dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian crew. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
The only time Rachel has been frightened is when she first went down with the Americans. There was an explosion and she thought, "I'm going to die."
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees those chimneys, there is such a sense of wonder.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe our appearance, our eye contact, our body language and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce was a teacher who worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job because the Head Teacher thought she didn't fit the image of an office manager.
Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression of a candidate. When our facial expressions and our words send different messages the listener will put more weight on the non-verbal message. So make sure your words agree with your body language.
Finally, a consideration of what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. If you are able to communicate clearly and concisely, you are more likely to make a good impression.

Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. He decided to leave his job and start a sheep farm. He was made redundant and had enough money to set up the farm. He also supplies meat through mail order.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. He decided to become an artist. He talked to a career counsellor and went to the north of England to start his new business.
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. She decided to set up her own business making hats. She feels happier and less stressed now.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance. He decided to become a masseur. He spent a year travelling and getting qualifications. He has no regrets.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports. They have to make sacrifices to be successful.
Darius is a runner. He has to train hard and be disciplined. He also has to give up late-night parties.
Gabriel is a surfer. He has to cut out late-night parties and give up lie-ins. He also has to be serious and professional.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He has to be traditional and celebrate wins in great style. He also has to be able to handle the attention that comes with being a celebrity.
Tomas is a tennis player. He has to travel a lot and be serious and professional. He also has to deal with the attention that comes with being a celebrity.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, they want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Parents sometimes have a hard time deciding which demands should be agreed to and which should be refused. They also admit they are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or even by providing supervised play areas.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

Where I get my energy, Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it. They said that doing things you enjoy gives you energy. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low even though you may be feeling tired. To get energy, you need to be positive and have a good sleep schedule. Exercise also gives you energy, but it's finding the energy to do it. If you're feeling low, eating something and getting some exercise can help you feel better.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bone. Now, people use skates made from metal. Skating is a popular sport that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. Once you have learned the basics, you can practice different styles of skating. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

There are many young people in the world who are passionate about their hobbies. Some of these hobbies include gymnastics, show-jumping, chess, and music.
A young girl named Julia Gregson won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She is ambitious and wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics.
Another young girl named Sarah Stokes made her first show-jumping appearance at ten. She is also ambitious and wants to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team and win a gold medal at the Olympics.
A young girl named Jane McShane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. She is also ambitious and wants to win a gold medal at the Olympics.
These young people are all passionate about their hobbies and are working hard to achieve their goals. They are an inspiration to everyone.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen. He is the tallest man in Britain today. Every decade, people in Europe grow taller. More and more people are born big. This does not mean humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors ate a wide variety of plants and fruits. But today, we eat mostly three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People often go to studio audiences to appear on television, take a look behind the scenes, or simply have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you are squashed among strangers and someone flashes cards with APPLAUD or LAUGH on them. You clap or laugh accordingly. This may reflect the reality of some television, but not all by any means.
Going to a studio may be a terrible way to watch television, but that's not what's important. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

Bruce, Sophia, Matthew, Annette, and James all have their favourite places in England. They like different landscapes, but they all appreciate the human element and the beauty of nature.
Bruce likes landscapes with old temples and villages. Sophia enjoys a miniature railway journey through back gardens. Matthew loves the remote and lovely coast. Annette prefers wide-open moorland for hiking. James purchased his favourite house, Glenthorne, where he can find peace and reconnect with his English roots.
Each person has their own unique way of experiencing their favourite place. Bruce finds beauty in the old temples and villages. Sophia finds joy in exploring the countryside and seeing people's daily lives. Matthew finds peace and tranquility on the coast. Annette finds solace in the feeling of space and freedom. James finds happiness in his own personal connection to the land.
They all appreciate the beauty and diversity of England's landscapes. They find their own special connection to the land, and they share their experiences with others.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. I was late getting home and when I arrived, there was a crisis. Domino the cat and Bianca the mouse were running around the bedroom. I tried to help, but I tripped over something and fell on the floor. The snake escaped and I was scared. I crouched like a rabbit and the snake was hissing and striking at me. I managed to capture Domino and pull the mouse from its jaws. I looked the snake over for weak points, but it didn't have any. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer and the snake relaxed. I eventually released the snake and it went away.
